subject: RE: Isolation or Collaboration
msgSnippet: Just 2 small points: ... [...] ... Sane state does NOT mean that everything can be done to the object at every time. Cedric s initialized example is
messageBody:
Just 2 small points:

J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Cedric Beust wrote:
>
> > Real code relies on dependencies all the time:
> >
[...]
>
> > - This method can only be invoked if such field has been
> initialized.
>
> All objects should be in a "sane" state all the time. If not,
> then the
> design could be improved to avoid this problem. The Pragmatic
> Programmers call what you describe as "Programming by Coincidence".
>

"Sane state" does NOT mean that everything can be done to the object at
every time. Cedric's "initialized" example is probably actually a design
flaw, but for other states, it makes of course much sense to disallow
certain operations: If a database connection is not open, you cannot
execute a select; if a file has been deleted, it cannot be deleted a
second time; a bill that has been cancelled cannot be invoiced; etc.etc.
In many cases I saw and see, programmers/designers/architects seem to
believe that the String class (where you can indeed execute every method
sensibly at every time) is the paradigmatic example of a class. Nothing
can be further from the truth: Many classes have an "interesting state
diagram", where certain operations can only be invoked if certain
conditions hold.

[...]
> > - A certain object can only be created if a previous object
> has been created
> > before.
>
> If so, then the previous object should be the only thing that
> can create
> the new object!

This is often contrary to design concepts with somewhat centralized
responsibilities. For example, if you look at the UML metamodel, an
association is a thing "between two (or more) classes" - so an
association (e.g. in an UML tool) can only be created when the classes
(e.g. class "icons") are there. Obviously, the order of the class
("icon") creation is not important - but both must be there. Usually,
one does not design this by giving the "icons" the responsibility of
creating the association (even in this case, the creating "icon" must
check whether the other one exists), but has a central "association
creation tool" which checks for the existence of the necessary icons.

Still, on a more general level - e.g. when one talks about closely tied
groups of classes (yes: they are there; not even one of the tutorials
that explain JUnit pretends that litterally everything makes sense to be
mocked) - the guidelines hinted at by JBR do make sense.

Regards
Harald M. Mueller
